div.head: To all truly vertuous LADIES.
div.p:

of what he writes. As for the pre≈øumption of this Addre≈øs, I am confident it will be ea≈øily excu≈øed in me, doing no more than what all the world does, while they endeavour to ≈øerve, with the utmo≈øt of their diligence, that Sex, for who≈øe reading this little VVork was chiefly intended. For the≈øe Secrets of Nature by which Nature hath taught us how to beautifie, and make her ≈øelf
more comely, coming to my hands, I could not chu≈øe but di≈øper≈øe them for the Benefit of tho≈øe to whom I owe ≈øo great a re≈øpect. To ≈øpeak of the things them≈øelves, they are ≈øuch, as the mo≈øt diligent Searchers into Natures Secrets, have delved out of her mo≈øt hidden and concealed Bowels, and compo≈øed by them with ≈øo much Art, and Experience, that for the certainty of
their Operation, they ≈øurpa≈øs, I may boldly ≈øay, what ever has been to this purpo≈øe yet made. Nor let any think it irreligion, to make Age endure comely and graceful, or to cover tho≈øe deformities by which the decay of Time renders a per≈øon not only unhand≈øom, but de≈øpicable? why ≈øhould a woman loo≈øe one of the chiefe≈øt Ornaments of her whole frame, a long Train of di≈øheveled Hair,

VVhy ≈øhould not the height of Cleanline≈øs be as much in commendation, as the height of Slutti≈øhne≈øs is di≈øcommended? Briefly therefore we ≈øhall ≈øay once more of this Treati≈øe, That there is nothing therein contained, but what the poor, as far as they are concerned (for all Phy≈øick it ≈øelf is not for their pur≈øe)
may u≈øe with profit, and the Rich both to their profit and plea≈øure. Therefore Ladies, buy the≈øe few Receipts, and make u≈øe of 'um, and if they fail, then never believe me another time; which di≈øplea≈øure of yours I would not willingly incur, out of my zeal always to appear,

div.head: SECTION I. A ≈øweet Water for the Body or Garments.
div.p: TAke of Ro≈øe-water, of Orange-flowers, of Myrtels, of Musk-water, each a pint, Powder of Oriental Orrice one ounce, Sivet a dram, mix them and boil them in a Gla≈øs ve≈ø≈øel, till a third part be wa≈øted, then keep in a Gla≈øs ve≈ø≈øel very well ≈øtopt.

div.head: A ≈øweet water of the Italians, which they call Damask-water.
div.p: TAke of cynamon one ounce, cloves half an ounce, ≈øweet-marjoram, ro≈øemary, lavender, Bay-leaves, penny-royal, green province ro≈øes, each a handful, mallego wine, ro≈øe-water, each a pint and a half, cut the green things, powder the dry ones, and ≈øet them in the Sun ≈øix dayes, then di≈øtill them in a double ve≈ø≈øel: ≈øome adde to them citron pill, ≈øtorax calamite, o ‚Ä¢ rice, each one dram, and flowers of ja≈ømine, they ≈øprinkle this water on their garments, linnen, hands, and no≈øtrils.

div.p:

div.head: Of Waters that make the Hair grow long.
div.p: TAke of lard as much as is ≈øufficient, ≈øhave it very thin, then beat it in a marble morter, that it may be like pa≈øte, then di≈øtil it in an Alembick, and you ≈øhall receive a white liquor, with which you mu≈øt anoint the Hair.

div.p: TAke of Gum-arabick four ounces, chebul and emblick, myrobalanes, each half a pound; being powdred and di≈øtilled by a gentle fire, ≈øet them in the ≈øun two hours, and the head being wa≈øht with a Ly, and dried, la≈øt of all wet the hairs with wine and ≈øalt, and wa≈øh them with the di≈øtilled water, but let it not touch the skin.

div.p: Take of privet and date-≈øtones powder'd, each alike, of the water in which bean rindes and gauls have been boyled, as much as is ≈øufficient, mix them.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Salt clen≈øed and brui≈øed, one pound, of Ice-alume one ounce, di≈øtil them in an Alembick, with an ounce of this water mix an ounce of plantane water, and rub the teeth with a Cotton cloth dipt in it.

div.head: Another precious one.
div.p: Take of the fir≈øt water of honey di≈øtilled, which is white, one pint, white Salt one ounce, Allom half a pound, ≈øalt Niter one ounce, water of the leaves of the Ma≈øtick tree one pint, Ma≈øtick, White-wine-vineger, each two ounces, di≈øtil them all in Bal: Mar: then rub the teeth with a Ma≈øtick ≈øtick dipt in it.

div.head: Another.
div.p:
Take of white Wine ≈øix ounces, the tops of Myrtil, Servas-tree, Cypre≈øs, each three ounces, Pomgranate flowers, the bark of Nut tree roots, Pellitory of Spain, Dragons blood, Date ≈øtones burnt, red Ro≈øe-buds, Cynamon, each one ounce, brui≈øe them and di≈øtil
them with a gentle fire; mix with two ounces of this water, one ounce of burnt Harts-horn, and one ounce of Dragons blood, and ≈øet them in the ≈øun four days, then rub your teeth with it.

div.head: A Water to ≈øtrengthen the Teeth.
div.p: Take three Nutmegs, two roots of Ginger, a little Ma≈øtick, Pellitory of Spain, ≈øweet Marjoram, Hy≈ø≈øop, Mint, Ro≈øemary, Sage, Salt, each half an ounce, put them all into ≈øweet wine, and let them boil till a third part be con≈øumed, then ≈øtrein it well, and u≈øe it hot.

div.head: A Decoction to fa≈øten the Teeth, clean≈øe, and ≈øtrengthen the Gums.
div.p: Take of the water of Ma≈øtick tree leaves, of Ro≈øemary, di≈øtilled Vineger, each half a pint, Myrrhe, Ma≈øtick, Bolearmenick, Dragons blood, burnt Alume, each one ounce, choice Cynamon half a dram, Rain-water three pints, mix them all and boil them with a very ≈ølow fire a quarter of an hour, adding of de≈øpumed Honey half a pint, a little Benjamin: wa≈øh the teeth often with this, holding it in your mouth a while.

div.head: Of Waters that adorn the Face.
div.p:
TAke of the Crum of Barley-bread two pound, of Goats milk three pints, white
wine half a pint, of the four greater cold ≈øeeds brui≈øed, each three ounces, Frankincen≈øe, Ma≈øtick, Myrrhe, each one ounce, fre≈øh Beans two pound, or Beans-flowers three ≈ømall handfuls, or of dryed Beans and red Cicers, each two pound; Rice half a pound, flowers of water Lillies, Violets, white Ro≈øes, each two ≈ømall handfuls; ten Eggs, di≈øtil them in Bal. Mar. If you adde Turpentine before you di≈øtil it, the liquor will be the better, and pre≈øerve the face the longer.

div.head: Another of the ≈øame.
div.p: Take of the Decoction of a Chicken, Capon, or Hen, three pints of the juice of Lemmons, one pint White wine vineger, half a pint Bean and Water-lilly-flowers, each three ≈ømall handfuls; Camphure and whites of Eggs, each two drams; mix them and di≈øtil them with an Alembick. In ≈øtead of the Decoction of a Capon or Hen, you may u≈øe the milk of a white Goat.

div.head: Another of the ≈øame.
div.p: Take of Bran ≈øeparated from the be≈øt grain, and of the ≈øtronge≈øt Vineger, each a ≈øufficient quantity, mix them and make a pa≈øte; to which adde in the mixing twelve whites of Eggs, and di≈øtil it.

div.head: A water to beautifie the Face.
div.p: Let the water made of the whites of new Eggs through a ≈øponge, with an equal quantity of Juice of Lemmons, be di≈øtilled as Ro≈øe-water; afterwards adde to this water two ounces or thereabouts, of common Lye, and put into it a whole Lemmon brui≈øed, after eight days pre≈øerve the Juice from it, and mix it with the water; let the face be fir≈øt wa≈øht with common water and dried, and then with this di≈øtilled water.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Ro≈øemary, white Tartar, white Wine, each a ≈øufficient quantity, mix them and di≈øtil them in an Alembick.

div.head: A water to make the face very fair.
div.p:
Take two young Pigeons, two pound of Veal, Spurge-≈øeeds clen≈øed four ounces, Pine Nuts, ≈øweet and bitter Almonds, the Roots of white and blew Lillies, Beans brui≈øed and clean≈øed, Ox-gaul, the Root of Gra≈øs Plantane, ba≈øtard Dittany, each as much as is ≈øufficient; one Lemmon cut and clean≈øed, the crum of white Bread ≈øteeped in Milk, Gumarmoniack di≈ø≈øolved in Vineger, Privet flowers, each a ≈øufficient quantity; mix them and di≈øtil them with a gentle fire, and put a little Musk and Benjamin about the top
of the neck of the Receiver, and keep it in a ve≈ø≈øel well ≈øtopt.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of green Pine-nuts clean≈øed and cut, as much as is ≈øufficient, put them in milk three days, every day adding new milk, then di≈øtil it with the things following, viz. Gla≈øs powder'd four ounces, red Coral three ounces, Sugar-candy four ounces, Allom one ounce, mix them and make a powder, then take of Quick≈øilver killed with ≈øpittle, one ounce and a half, twelve new laid Eggs ≈øhels and all, broken and beaten together, Turpentine nine times wa≈øht four ounces, white Sea-periwinkles which Perfumers ≈øell, two ounces, Earth-≈ønails fifty, brui≈øe them all, and mix them, then put in part into a Gla≈øsgoard, and then part of the powder, afterwards part of the Turpentine, la≈øt of all part of the ≈ønails, thus laying one upon another till the Goard be full, then adde a ≈øufficient quantity of white Wine, and with a ≈ølow fire di≈øtil it for your u≈øe.

div.head: A Mellon Water to beautifie the Face.
div.p:
Take of white Mellons clean≈øed from the Rine, as many as needs, and cut them into pieces a finger thick, then take of Sugar'd-allom four ounces, Burnt-allom, Quick≈øilver kill'd, each one ounce, white Sea-periwinkles
two ounces, wa≈øht Turpentine one ounce, twelve new laid Egges brui≈øed with their ≈øhells, white Lemmons cut in pieces, as many as you plea≈øe, Sugar four ounces, Goats milk, white wine, each a ≈øufficient quantity, put all the≈øe in a Gla≈øs-goard, one upon another, as hath been ≈øaid, then di≈øtil them with a gentle fire, and keep it in a gla≈øs ve≈ø≈øel for your u≈øe.

div.head: A compleat Goard-water.
div.p: Take as many Goards as you plea≈øe, clean≈øed from the Rines, and cut in round pieces, Sugar'd-alume ≈øix ounces, Alume one ounce, Myrrhe a dram, wa≈øht Turpentine half an ounce, four new laid Eggs brui≈øed, ≈øix Lemmons ≈øliced, Snailes as many as you plea≈øe, white Wine a ≈øufficient quantity. Powder what is to be powder'd and mix them, laying the fir≈øt row with Sugar, then with powders, the third with Snails, the la≈øt with Wine, Lemmons, and Eggs, and ≈øo di≈øtil them with a gentle fire, then keep it in a gla≈øs ve≈ø≈øel eight or fifteen days.

div.head: A water to ≈øet forth the Face.
div.p:
Take two Calves feet, twelve pints of rain water, boyl away half, then adde one pound of Rice, the Crumb of one Loaf ≈øoftned in Milk, two pound of fre≈øh Butter, ten whites of Eggs with the ≈øhells, mix them all and
boyl them, then di≈øtil them; to which at la≈øt adde a little Camphure and Sugar'd-alume, and it will be excellent.

div.head: Another of the ≈øame.
div.p: Take of Chry≈øocol or Borax two ounces, of Roche-alume, Sci≈øsil, Squammous, each one ounce, Camphure two drams, powder them all, then mix them, and put them in a gla≈øs vial filled with ≈øpring-water, and clo≈øe ≈øtopt, then ≈øet it to the fire two hours, then take it away, and when it is cold put it into another vial, adding two whites of new laid Eggs beaten well together with the Juice of unripe Grapes, and you will have a mo≈øt compleat water.

div.head: A water to adorn the Face.
div.p: Take Eggs cut in pieces, Orange-pills, the roots of Mellons, each as much as is ≈øufficient, in a large ve≈ø≈øel with a long neck di≈øtil it by an Alembick with a ≈øtrong and careful fire.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Bean-flowers ≈øix handfuls, Lemmon water one pint, Lilly roots eight ounces, Bean-flour one pound, Gum-arabick and Tragacanth, each one ounce, di≈øtil them, and u≈øe it.

div.head: Another.
div.p:
Take of Fennel, Rue, Vervin, Eyebright, Endive, Betony, Mountain-≈øiler, red Ro≈øes,
Maidenhair, each ≈øix handfuls, infu≈øe them a day and night in white wine, then di≈øtil them in an Alembick.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of white Beanes clean≈øed from the Rine, as much as you plea≈øe, ≈øteep them in white Wine nine days, then brui≈øe them and put them in again; to which adde Rice boyled in Goats milk, whites of Eggs, each a ≈øufficient quantity, mix them all, & di≈øtil them.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of fre≈øh unripe Barley, Goats milk, whites of Egges, each a ≈øufficient quantity, mix and di≈øtil them.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Lemmons, dried Beans, ≈øteeped in Wine, Honey, Goats milk, the whites of Eggs, each a ≈øufficient quantity, mix and di≈øtil them.

div.head: Another of the ≈øame.
div.p: Take of Cowes milk in the moneth of May two pints, three Oranges, five Lemmons, cut them ≈ømall, then adde of Alume, Sugar, each one ounce, mix them all, then di≈øtil them.

div.head: Another to make the Face bright.
div.p:
Take of the Crumb of white Bread two pound, Bean-flowers one pint, flowers of Ro≈øes, Water-lillies, Lillies, each four pints, Goats milk ≈øix drams, Venetian Flower-deluce
one ounce, di≈øtil them in Balneo Mariae.

div.head: Another of the ≈øame.
div.p: Take of Turpentine, the white≈øt Ma≈øtick, Tutty prepared, Camphure, Alume, each four ounces, infu≈øe them three days in ≈øharp Vineger, then di≈øtil them in an Alembick.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of fre≈øh Gra≈øs-plantane one ounce, Rue one handful, Ground-ivy two handfuls, Borax one ounce, Wood of Aloes one dram, Styrax-calamite half an ounce, Musk half a ≈øcruple, Unguent three ounces, Camphure ≈øix drams, the fle≈øh of a Capon two ounces, Lemmon and Orange Pill, each one pound: di≈øtil them.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Camphure three drams, red Alume, Borax, each ≈øix ounces, Musk two ≈øcruples, brui≈øe them all, and then adde of Tartar one ounce and half, Ro≈øe-water two pints, mix them well with a ≈øpattle, then di≈øtil it thorow a Filter, and keep it in a Vial well ≈øhut, then with a cloth take a drop or two of the water, and rub the face.

div.head: Of Waters that colour and whiten the face.
div.p: Take of wilde Rue, Fennel, Vervin, roots of Betony, Ro≈øe-leaves, Maidenhair, each alike parts, ≈øteep them all night in fragrant white wine, and di≈øtil them in an Alembi ‚Ä¢ k.

div.head: Another of the ≈øame.
div.p: Take of Cuckow-pintle as much as is ≈øufficient, brui≈øe the thicker parts, & with Ro≈øe-water dry them by the Sun three or four times, and pouring more Ro≈øe-water on it, u≈øe it.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take the white of an Egg, of rocky Borax, Salt, Roche-alume, each one ounce, powder them ≈øeverally, mix them with the whites of Eggs and di≈øtil them, and ≈øo u≈øe it.

div.head: Another of the ≈øame.
div.p: Take of Roche-alume powder'd three ounces, whites of Eggs as much as is ≈øufficient, mix and di≈øtil them.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take the Flowers of Water-lilly, white Thorn, Elder, Beans, Violets, Maidenhair, each equal parts, mix and di≈øtil them.

div.head: Another of the ≈øame.
div.p: Take of Lytharge powder'd half a pound, boyl it in three ounces of white wine Vineger, and ≈øtrein it through a cloth, and put it in a gla≈øs ve≈ø≈øel, then adde Camphure, Ja≈ømine, Alume, Borax, Oyl of Tartar, each alike parts, Ro≈øe-water as much as is ≈øufficient, mix them and di≈øtil them.

div.head: Another approved one of the Authors.
div.p:

each half an ounce, powder them and mix them with Turpentine-water and di≈øtil them again; then take of fre≈øh Hogs-grea≈øe melted, one pound, Cloves two drams, three Nutmegs, Gold one dram, Silver two drams, powder them finely and di≈øtil them in an Alembick.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Bean-leaves ten handfuls, Roche-alume one pound and a half, Sugar'd-alume five drams; Endive, Alume, four ounces and a half, ≈øalt Niter three ounces, the Lees of Alume ≈øix ounces, Quick≈øilver killed three ounces; di≈øtil it with a ≈ølow fire, and when it begins to drop increa≈øe the fire.

div.head: Another of the ≈øame.
div.p: Take of Ja≈ømine, Alume, Borax, Roche-alume, all powder'd, each three ounces, the whites of Eggs as much as is ≈øufficient; di≈øtil them.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of choice Silver, Quick≈øilver, each one ounce, powder them on a Marble≈øtone, and adding a little Sublimate, ≈øet them in a moi≈øt place, and di≈øtil in an Alembick that which is melted.

div.head: Another to make the Face bright.
div.p:
Take of the roots of Lillies, Cuckow-pintle, Dragons, each half a pound; the Water of Bean-flowers a pint and a half, Ro≈øe-water eight ounces; di≈øtil them, adding Musk,

div.p: Take of live Sulphur one ounce, white Frankincen≈øe two ounces, Camphure one dram, Ro≈øe-water a pint, powder them and mix them, and ≈øet them in the ≈øun fifteen days, and wa≈øh the face with it at night, but in the morning wa≈øh it with the Decoction of Bran and Ro≈øes.

div.p: Take of Rain-water, the Juice of unripe Grapes, each alike quantity, boyl them together till one half be con≈øumed, then whi≈øes it boyls adde ≈øo much Juice of Lemmons as was boyled away before, then when it is boyled enough, take it from the fire and adde four whites of Eggs after it is cold, and keep it for your u≈øe.

div.p: Take of Aquavitae four times di≈øtilled, three parts, the tops of Ro≈øemary-flowers, two parts, ≈øteep them together a day and a night in a ve≈ø≈øel well ≈øtopt, then di≈øtil them.

div.head: The Water of a certain Noble-woman.
div.p:
Take of Sublimate one ounce, Camphure one dram, powder them very wel, then infu≈øe
them in the Juice of Lemmons, Ro≈øe-water, white Lilly, Goard, and Bean-flower-water, each half a pint, ≈øet them in the ≈øun fifteen days, and keep it for your u≈øe.

div.p: Take of Goats milk three pints, the Crum of two white Loaves, mix them together ≈øix hours, then adde Lemmons clean≈øed from their pill, twelve whites of Eggs, Lime, Egg-≈øhell, Venus-≈øhell, each half an ounce, Camphure, Alume, red Corral, each two drams, Borax one ounce, Ceru≈ø≈øe three ounces, mix them and di≈øtil them with care.

div.head: Another of the ≈øame Authors.
div.p: Take of the Flowers of Beans, of Water-lillies, each one pound, the Crum of white Bread, the Flower of Rice, of Orrice root, of wilde Cowcumber, each ≈øix ounces, honey one pint, white Wine, Spring-water, each three pints, mix them and di≈øtil them in Bal. Mariae, adding Goard-≈øeeds clean≈øed three ounces; Frankincen≈øe, Myrrhe, each one ounce, and keep it for your u≈øe.

div.head: Another to whiten Skars.
div.p:
Take of the roots of Orrice, wilde Cow-cumber, each three pound, the roots of Mar≈øh mallows, Lillies, each two pound, ripe Grapes half a pound, Dittander roots three ounces,
the plant of Beanes, Pellitory of the wall, each one handful; the Flowers of Water-lillies, Mallows, each a ≈ømall handful; Barley bread one pound, ≈øteep them in white Wine or Goats whey, and di≈øtil them; then add of Raddi≈øh half an ounce, the four greater cold Seeds, each one dram, a Boys urine half a pint; ≈øet them in the ≈øun, and keep them for your u≈øe.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Brim≈øtone, Salt, each half an ounce, Camphure, Tutty, each one dram; Ro≈øe-water two ounces and a half, powder them and mix them.

div.head: A Water to whiten the Face.
div.p: Take of the Juice of Lemmons one ounce, of Venus-≈øhell five ounces, ≈øteep them till they are di≈ø≈øolved, then adde twelve Lemmons ≈øliced, ten whites of Eggs, Camphure, Borax, each one dram and a half; Water of Pine-apples half a pint, mix and di≈øtil them.

div.head: Another of the ≈øame Authors.
div.p:
Take of the ≈øcum of Silver half a pound, white wine vineger three pints, boyl them till a third part be con≈øumed and di≈øtil them, then adde to the di≈øtilled water Camphure half an ounce, Endive, Alume, Oyl of Tartar, Sugar'd-alume, each one ounce, leave them ≈øo till they are di≈ø≈øolved, afterwards
≈øtrein it, and keep it ≈øafe for your u≈øe.

div.head: A Water for a Red-face.
div.p: Take of the roots of round Birthwort, of white and red ≈øpatling poppy, each half an ounce, Orrice roots five ounces, Lilly roots ≈øix ounces, red Vetches, burnt Lupines, each half a pugil; Nutmeg, Cynamon, each half a dram, bitter Almonds brui≈øed two ounces, Oyl of Tartar four ounces, Rain-water two pints, the blood of a Hare, as much as is ≈øufficient, powder and di≈øtil them.

div.head: A Water to whiten the Face.
div.p: Take of white Ro≈øes, the Flowers of Water-lillies, Elder, white Lillies, each one pound, Bean-flower water half a pint, the crum of bread a ≈øufficient quantity, twelve whites of Eggs; Frankincen≈øe two ounces, powder of Ceru≈ø≈øe one pound, mix them and di≈øtil them.

div.p: Take of Goats milk, Flour of Bread-corn, each a ≈øufficient quantity, work them into the form of a Loaf, and bake it in an Oven, then take the Crum of this Bread ≈øteeped in Goats milk, twelve whites of Eggs and di≈øtil them; adde to the di≈øtilled water, of Lime one ounce, Camphure, Sugar'd-alume, white Curral, each two drams, powder and mix them, and di≈øtil them again.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of white Tartar, white Wine, Ro≈øemary flowers, each a ≈øufficient quantity; mix and di≈øtil them.

div.head: Another very good one.
div.p: Take ≈øix new laid Eggs, half a pint of Mallego wine, young Pigeons, new Chee≈øe without ≈øalt, each one, eight Oranges, Oyl of Tartar three ounces, Ceru≈ø≈øe one ounce, brui≈øe them, mix them and di≈øtil them.

div.head: Another of the ≈øame Authors.
div.p: Take thirty Snailes, two pints of Goats milk, Hogs-grea≈øe three ounces, Camphure one dram; powder the Camphure by it ≈øelf, them brui≈øe them all together & di≈øtil them.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take the crum of white bread ≈øteeped in a ≈øufficient quantity of Goats or A≈ø≈øes milk, & di≈øtil it.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Myrrhe two ounces, Frankincen≈øe, Ma≈øtick, each half an ounce, white Ginger three drams, choice Cynamon, Sublimate, each two drams, Camphure one dram, the whites of Eggs one pint; powder them & put them in the belly of a hen, adding three pints of Goats or A≈ø≈øes milk, and di≈øtil them.

div.head: A Water to whiten the Face, and take away Freckles.
div.p:
Take of Borax one ounce, Camphure one
dram, Roche-alume three drams, Gum-arabick, Tragacanth, each half an ounce; Sarcocol, ‚Ä¢ weet A≈øa, each two ounces, Ceru≈ø≈øe four ounces, powder them and adde the Water of Gra≈øs-plantain; of Lilly flowers, of Broom flowers, of Water-lillies, each half a pint, mix and di≈øtil them.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: Take four young Pigeons, fre≈øh Butter, or the fat of Milk four ounces, the whites of twelve new laid Eggs, the root of Salomons-≈øeal twelve drams, Borax two ounces, Flour of Cry≈øtal three ounces; Camphure, Endive, Alume, Sugar'd-alume, each half an ounce; water of Goards twelve ounces, water of ≈øowr Grapes three ounces; powder what is to be powder'd, then mix and di≈øtil them.

div.head: Another excellent one of the ≈øame Authors.
div.p: Take two pints of white wine vineger, one pint of Ro≈øe-water, water of Orenge-pills, and Orenge-flowers, each ≈øix ounces, Whorehound one handful, honey half a pint, Musk three graines, Cloves four drams, Sugar'd-alume two ounces, Ma≈øtick one ounce, powder and di≈øtil them.

div.head: Another.
div.p:
Take four Lemmons, Sugar-candy half an ounce, the Juice of wilde Grapes one pint four ounces, A≈ø≈øes milk half a pint, the whites
of eight new laid Eggs, the Crum of white Bread three ounces, Camphure one dram and a half, Bean-flowers two pound, mix and di≈øtil them.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take the Juice of green Cane, the Juice of Gentian, of Hou≈øleek, of Lemmons, each two ounces; A≈ø≈øes milk ≈øix ounces, Bean-flower water two pints, white Curral three ounces; Venus-≈øhell di≈ø≈øolved in Juice of Lemmons one ounce, Borax half an ounce; powder and di≈øtil them.

div.head: Of Waters that make the Face red.
div.p: To make the face ruddy, u≈øe ≈øhavings of Brazzeel di≈ø≈øolved in Ro≈øe-water with a little Camphure.

div.head: A Water to colour the Face.
div.p: Take white young Pigeons, feed them fifteen days with Pine-nuts, then open them, ca≈øt away their heads, feet and bowels, and then take half a loaf, Sugar'd-alume as much as is ≈øufficient; five hundred leaves of Gold, three hundred of Silver, the crum of four white loaves ≈øoaked in the milk of ≈øweet Almonds, the marrow of a Calf, or Ox, or Hogsgrea≈øe one pound, mix them and di≈øtil them.

div.head: A red Water for the Face.
div.p:
Take five and twenty whites of Eggs boyled hard, a cup full of the milk of Figs, mix
and di≈øtil them; then adde to this water for every pint, two ounces of Sci≈øsil-alume, Dyers Grain half an ounce, Berries with which Silk is dyed, two drams; mix them and put them in a gla≈øs Vial well ≈øtopt, in dung, or in warm water for eight days, then take them out, and ≈øtrein and pre≈øs them very well; which being done, add again as much Alume and Berries as before, and put it likewi≈øe in dung or warm water for eight days, and ≈øtrein them again as formerly; which when it is done three times, add half an ounce of Gum-arabick to one pint of water, & leave it eight days in a warm place, as before; and la≈øt of all ≈øtrein it and keep it for your u≈øe.

div.head: Another more ea≈øe, and of le≈øs price.
div.p: Take of the Glew of fi≈øhes di≈ø≈øolved five or ≈øix days in white wine, two ounces, Brazzeel ≈ølized, as much as is ≈øufficient, Spring-water a ≈øufficient quantity, mix and boyl them with a very ≈ølow fire till it is enough, then adde powder of Alume one ounce, Gum-arabick two drams; mix them, then taking it from the fire, keep it in a ve≈ø≈øel very well ≈øtopt.

div.head: Another to make the face red.
div.p:
Take of the Root of Salomons-≈øeal ten ounces, the roots of Sows-bread five ounces, of Gra≈øs-plantane or Cuckow-pintle, one ounce; clean Lard one ounce and a half, five
Lemmons ≈øliced, the Crum of white Bread ≈øteeped in milk, as much as is ≈øufficient; Sublimate, Endive, Alume, each two ounces Roche-alume one ounce and a half, Venus ≈øhell di≈ø≈øolved in the Juice of Lemmons, one ounce; mix and di≈øtil them.

div.p:

div.p: Take a ≈øufficient quantity of white Wine, the a≈øhes of Maidenhair burnt, a pretty good quantity, boil them together to wa≈øh the hair.

div.p: Take the roots of Mar≈øh-mallows boyled in water, pre≈øs them and ≈øtrein them, and add to it the ≈øeed of Flax, Fleawort, each a ≈øufficient quantity, afterwards ≈øtrein it and mix it exactly, and rhen wa≈øh the hair.

div.p: Take the flour of Fenegrick, Henbane, Litharge of gold, each equal parts, put them in a Lye, with which wa≈øh the hair.

div.head: Another.
div.p:

Beets, each a ≈øufficient quantity, boyl them together till a third part be con≈øumed, then take it from the fire, and add of Gum-arabick as much as will ≈øuffice, mix them and make a Lotion, with which wa≈øh the hair, and when they are dried, wet them with Oyl of Myrtles.

div.head: Of Oyls that adorn the Face.

div.p: Take of burnt Tartar half a pound, powder it and dry it as they do ≈øalt, then take that ≈øalt and put it within the whites of Egges boyled.

div.p:

div.p: Take four ounces of Peach Kernels, Goard≈øeed two ounces, brui≈øe them & make an Oyl to anoint the face morning and evening.

div.p: Take of common Oyl, Ro≈øemary-flowers, each one part, mix them and put them in a gla≈øs vial under hor≈øe dung, for three weeks or a moneth, then ≈øtrein it and ≈øet it in the ≈øun for ≈øome days, and ≈øo u≈øe it.

div.p: Oyl of Tartar takes away wrinckles of the face; al≈øo Oyl of bitter Almonds, and Oyl of Lillies.

div.p: Take of Ro≈øemary-≈ølowers, as much as is ≈øufficient, bury them in a gla≈øs ve≈ø≈øel under dung ≈øafe from rain, keep it thirty days, and that which is di≈ø≈øolved, expo≈øe to the ≈øun for nine days, with powder of Polypodie mixt, as much as you can take in three fingers; of which take every day for a moneth.

div.head: An Oyl for a Ringworm in the face.
div.p: Take a green live Lizard, boyl it in wine and oyl, till the wine be con≈øumed, then ≈øtrein it and u≈øe it. Oyl of Mezereon, Oyl of A≈øh, Oyl of Eggs, do likewi≈øe take away all ≈øpots and ≈øpeckles of the face.

div.head: Oyls to pre≈øerve and increa≈øe the Hair.
div.p: FIll a wild Goard, (ca≈øting away that which is in it) with Oyl of Bayes, and adding Henbane-feed and yellow Ar≈ønick, anoint the hairs.

div.p: Take the ≈øeeds of Mar≈øh-mallows, a ≈øufficient quantity, boyl them in common Oyl, with which anoint the hairs.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Al≈øo the Oyl of Earth-vvorms doth increa≈øe the hair.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of ≈øowr Grapes juiced, ≈øix ounces, Oyl of Ma≈øtick, Oyl of Myrtle, Oyl of Labdanum, each two ounces, Maidenhair four ounces, boyl them till the Juice of Grapes be con≈øumed, and anoint the hair with the Oyl.

div.p: It is made as Oyl of Rue, it is good to cau≈øe hair grow; and in ≈øhedding of hair it is anointed with Labdanum and Bears fat.

div.head: Of Oyls that colour the Hair.
An Oyl to black it.
div.p: OYl made of green Lizards doth black the hair.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Privet, Vitriol, common Oyl, each a ≈øufficient quantity, ≈øet them to the fire till they begin to boyl, then keep it to anoint the hair.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of the Juice of the rines of Sallow, common oyl, or Oyl of Co≈øtmary, each a ≈øufficient quantity, mix them and anoint the hair.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take a hundred green Nuts, common Oyl a pint and a half, liquid Alume three pound, put all the≈øe together into a new earthen ve≈ø≈øel fir≈øt made wet, and being carefully anointed about, ≈øet is in a place not too moi≈øt nor too hot, and let it be under the earth three moneths, then take it away and u≈øe the Oyl.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take the Juice of red Poppy, the Juice of green Nuts, Oyl of Myrtles, Oyl of Co≈øtmary, each one part, boyl it a while and anoint the hair.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Emblick, Myrobalanes one ounce, of the binding Bean-tree ten drams, Gauls, Acorn-cups, Myrtle-berries, Sumach, each ten drams, Oyl of unripe Olives, Oyl of ≈øweet Almonds, each eleven ounces, Labdanum three ounces, a little Vineger; mix them and boyl it till the Vineger be con≈øumed, and ≈øo u≈øe it.

div.head: Another.
div.p: If a wilde Goard, the ≈øeeds being taken out, be filled with Oyl, or as others will have it, with Oyl of Bays, and the whole ≈øeeds of black Henbane, and be ≈øet ≈øo a day and a night in a warm place, and the hairs be anointed with the oyl, it blacks them, and keeps off gray hairs.

div.head: An Oyl to make the hair yellow.
div.p: Take of choice Myrrhe, the root of the greater Madder, the root of Celandine, each alike parts, powder them all, and boyl them in oyl in which ≈øhavings or pieces of Box and Saftron have been fir≈øt boyled; with this annoint the hair, being often wa≈øht with a Lye made of the ≈øpirits of Beans and Barley.

div.p: Take of Oyl of Turkey-millet one mea≈øure, flowers of Matweed cut, three ounces; white Lilly-≈øeeds one ounce, Turmerick two drams, Saffron half a dram, Cynamon, Benjamin, Musk, Sivet, each a little; mix them all and put them in a gla≈øs Vial, and ≈øet it in the ≈øun a whole ≈øummer; with this Oyl annoint the comb, then comb the hair in the ≈øun, and cover the head combed with a warm cloth gen ‚Ä¢ ly that it do not pre≈øs it.

div.head: An Oyl to dye the hair red.
div.p: Take of burnt Tartar, Oyl of Ma≈øtick, Rozen of the Pine-tree, each as much as is ≈øufficient, mix and anoint the hair with it.

div.p: Take three green Lizards, Oyl of Myrtles, as much as is ≈øufficient, boyl them together till their fle≈øh be di≈ø≈øolved, and anoint the comb.

div.head: Another of the ≈øame Authors.
div.p: Take of Emblick, Myrobalanes, a ≈øufficient quantity, ≈øteep them in Oyl of Turky-millet till they ≈øwell, then boyl them together a quarter of an hour.

div.head: An Oyl to pre≈øerve Travellers from cold.
div.p: Fir≈øt chafe the extream parts well, then annoint them with the oyl of Euphorbium heated, with oyl of Pellitory of Spain, and oyl of Peppers.

div.head: Of Ointments that hinder ≈øhedding the hair.
div.p: Take of Labdanum ≈øteeped in ‚Ä¢ owr wine, and powder'd, a ≈øufficient quantity, Oyl of Myrtles what will ≈øuffice; mix them and make an Unguent, wi ‚Ä¢ h which anoint the hair before bathing.

div.head: Another of the ≈øame.
div.p: Take two parts of Labdanum, Oyl of Myrtles, Wine, each a ≈øufficient quantity, Maidenhair one part, make an Unguent.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Myrtle-berries, Labdanum, each three ounces; with the Decoction of binding Bean-tree, boyl it to a thickne≈øs, then adde Oyl of Nard or Myrtles, a ≈øufficient quantity, make an Unguent.

div.head: Another to pre≈øerve the hair, and make them black.
div.p:

div.p: Take a pint and a half of Candy-wine ≈øodden, Labdanum one ounce, the ‚Ä¢ ine of Pinenuts burnt, two ounces; Maidenhair burnt, one ounce, Bears-grea≈øe one pound, juice of Beets three cups full, boyl the Labdanum and Wine till they come into one body, then put in the re≈øt, and taking them away, keep it in a leaden ve≈ø≈øel.

div.p: Take Small age ≈øeeds two ounces, Maidenhair, Frankincen≈øe, each two ounces, fifteen Walnuts, Labdanum two ounces, rines of Pine-nuts one pound, put them all into a new earthen ve≈ø≈øel well ≈øtopt with clay, and burn them in the furnace of a bath, then take them out and powder them, and add of Bears fat one pound, work them into a body and put them in an oaken or Cypre≈øs Box; and at time of u≈øe, take as much as will be needful, and beat it up with what ≈øweet ointment you plea≈øe, & anoint the head with it twice a day

div.p: Take of dried Coleworts a ≈øufficient quantity, powder it, and with water bring it into the form of an Unguent, and u≈øe it.

div.p: Take Labdanum ≈øprinkled with ≈øowr wine, powder it, and with Oyl of Myrtles and wine poured to it by cour≈øe, bring it to the thickne≈øs of Honey, and anoint the head with it before and after a bath.

div.p: Take Juice of ≈øowr Grapes, or unripe wine, a pint and a half, Labdanum one ounce, the rine of Pine-nuts burnt two ounces, Maidenhair burnt three ounces, the fat of a Bear or Duck four ounces, Juice of Night-≈øhade half an ounce; boyl the Wine and Labdanum together, then add the re≈øt and keep it for u≈øe.

div.p: Take of Labdanum th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e ounces, Gaules, Myrrhe, Ma≈øtick, Frankincen≈øe, each one dram, wilde Carduus two drams, di≈ø≈øolve them all in oyl of Ro≈øes, and ≈øo u≈øe it.

div.p:

one ounce, Maidenhair one pound, an A≈ø≈øes member, an A≈ø≈øes ≈øpleen, Labdanum, each one pound, ≈øteep the Labdanum in a little wine, and melt the fat with the ≈øteem of water, burn the A≈ø≈øes member and ≈øhave it, but burn the Spleen in a new pot with Maidenhair, and powder and ≈øearce what ought to be, then make them with new wine, and u≈øe it before bathing, the head being fir≈øt comb'd.

div.p: Take of Oyl of ≈øweet Almonds, Myrrhe, each an ounce, the rine of the roots of Reeds burnt, Maidenhair burnt, each two drams, heads of Flies burnt, Bees brui≈øed in their emptine≈øs, each half a dram, Labdanum two drams, Honey one ounce, powder them, and with a little Wax, make a Liniment.

div.p:

Dock, each one handful, Pockwood half a pound, make a Decoction and u≈øe it as hath been ≈øaid.

div.p: Take of Fenigreek ≈øix pints, Flax-≈øeed three pints, Labdanum eight ounces, the Juice of binding Bean-tree two ounces, of the Indian leaf two ounces, twenty Gauls, Aromatical Onyx two ounces, Syrian Cane two ounces and a half, Bdellium two ounces, Myrtle burnt twenty four ounces, Musk three ounces, Florence Flower-de-luce two ounces, powder them ≈øeverally, ≈øearce them and mix them.

div.p: Take the a≈øhes of Gra≈øhoppers burnt, of Bees burnt, Oyl of Myrtles or fat, each a ≈øufficient quantity, mix them and make an Unguent.

div.p: Take the Decoction of Spurge mixt with Vineger, un≈ølaked Lime and Mallows.

div.head: Another.
div.p:
Take the blood of Bats, the Juice of Ivy,
the Juice of Radi≈øh, Goats Suet, each a ≈øufficient quantity, mix them and make an ointment.

div.head: Another.

div.p: Take of Opium, Henbane, each a ≈øufficient quantity, powder them, and with Vineger bring them into the form of an Unguent, with which anoint the hairs daily.

div.head: Another.

Oyl of bitter Almonds, each two ounces, mix them and make an Unguent.

div.head: An Ointment for hands ≈øwelled with cold.
div.p: Take the grea≈øe of Wooll, Goo≈øe, and Ducks grea≈øe, the mucilage of Quince-≈øeeds, each two ounces, Starch-corn ≈øix drams, Turpentine one ounce and a half, Oyl of Ro≈øes, Oyl of yelks of Eggs, each two ounces, yellow Wax a little, make a Liniment.

div.head: Another to wa≈øh the hands.
div.p: Take of Pine-nuts clean≈øed, powder of Mu≈øtard-≈øeed, each three ounces, the be≈øt Honey half a pint, mix them and make a pa≈øte.

div.head: Another for hands ≈øwelled with cold.
div.p: Take the ≈øeeds of Flax, Fenigreek, Mar≈øhmallows, each half a dram, of Mucilage extracted of Lilly-water, and the fore-mentioned ointment, each one ounce, oyl of Dill, oyl of ≈øweet Almonds, each half an ounce, make a Liniment for the hands with cour≈øe Wooll.

div.head: For Clefts of the hands.
div.p: Take ointment of Litharge, of Ceru≈ø≈øe, each one dram, mix them.

div.head: Another.
div.p:
Take of Rams-grea≈øe, Starch-corn, Litharge,
Oyl, each a ≈øufficient quantity, make an Unguent.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Litharge of Silver, Myrrhe, Ginger, each a like parts; Honey, Wax, Oyl, each a ≈øufficient quantity, make an Unguent.

div.head: Another for clefts of the Hands and cold.
div.p: Take of common Oyl four ounces, white Frankincen≈øe, clean Wax, each one ounce, the Juice of Elder-leaves three ounces, well ≈øcented white wine four ounces, boyl an Apple in the Wine, Oyl and Juice of Elder, afterwards adde the Frankincen≈øe and Wax, and then ≈øtrein it.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Anoint them with the roots of ≈øoure Dock and Sows-grea≈øe.

div.head: Another for the clefts of the hands.
div.p: Take of Ma≈øtick, Oyl of Ro≈øes, white Wax, each a ≈øufficient quantity, make an Unguent.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Bran burnt to a≈øhes, the hairs of a Hor≈øe tail burnt, each one part, Honey as much as is ≈øufficient, make an Unguent.

div.head: Another.
div.p:
Take of Tutty, Ceru≈ø≈øe, Litharge, each half a dram, Ar≈ønick, Sublimate three granes,
Lead, Alume, each half a ≈øcruple, Water of Ro≈øes, Plantane, Pur≈ølane, each a ≈øufficient quantity, the white of one Egg, make a mixture.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Tragacanth one ≈øcruple, flour of Starch-corn half an ounce, Juice of Plantane two drams, with Syrup of Ro≈øes make a mixture.

div.head: An Ointment for ≈øcabby and leprous Nails.
div.p: Take of Rams fat, Colophony, each two drams, mix them.

div.head: A Cerot for the ≈øame.
div.p: Take of Turpentine, Cummin, each one dram, mix them.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take Oyl of Ma≈øtick, unripe Olives, each two ounces, Cynamon one dram, Ceru≈ø≈øe wa≈øht, burnt Lead, each half a dram, Tutty prepared ≈øix drams, white Wax, Rozen wa≈øht with wine, each one ounce, mix them.

div.head: An Ointment for a contu≈øion of the nails.
div.p: Take of new Wax, Cummin, Co≈øtmary, each a ≈øufficient quantity, pouder them and mix them up with the Wax.

div.head: Another.
div.p:
Take of Ducks-grea≈øe, Bears fat, Euphorbium
pouder'd, each a ≈øufficient quantity, make an Unguent.

div.head: An Ointment for Clefts of the nails.
div.p: Take of Diachylon, Oyl of Almonds, Oyl of Been, Ma≈øtick, Rai≈øons, each a ≈øufficient quantity, make a Plai≈øter.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Flax-≈øeed, Honey, each a ≈øufficient quantity, mix them to the form of a Plai≈øter.

div.head: For leprous Nails.
div.p: Take of Pitch and Wax, each a ≈øufficient quantity, melt them together, and make an Unguent.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Goats Suet, Sandarach pouder'd, each a ≈øufficient quantity.

div.head: For pill'd Nails.
div.p: Take of Salt, Flour of Barley, Co≈øtmary powder'd, each one part, Honey a ≈øufficient quantity, mix them.

div.head: An Ointment after ≈øhedding of the nails.
div.p: Take of Flax-≈øeed one ounce, Cardamoms three drams, Honey a ≈øufficient quantity, mix them.

div.head: An Ointment to make the nails fall.
div.p: Take ointment of Ro≈øes, Cantharides, each a ≈øufficient quantity, mix them.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take Mi≈ø≈øletoe of the oak, Ar≈ønick, each a ≈øufficient quantity, mix them.

div.head: An Ointment for warts in the Hands.
div.p: Take the roots of a Vine, ≈øheeps-dung, and Goats-dung, each one part, the milk of Figs or of Spurge, as much as is ≈øufficient, make an Unguent.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take the Lees of Oyl, Sugar-alume, each one ounce, Verdegrea≈øe two ounces, Tar half an ounce, mix them and u≈øe them.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take ru≈øt of Bra≈øs, yellow Ar≈ønick, Dates, un≈ølaked Lime, froth of the Sea, Tartar, Vitriol, Pigeons-dung, the floure of Rie, of Gith, each equal parts, Bulls-gaul, as much as is ≈øufficient, make an Unguent to lay on the Warts fir≈øt ≈øcarified.

div.head: Another.
div.p: The bark of Sallow burnt, and mixt with Vinegar, and laid on; al≈øo a Dogs-turd with Wax.

div.head: Of Ointments that adorn the Bre≈øt.
To keep the Brea≈øts ≈ømall.
div.p:
TAke of Roch-alume pouder'd a ≈øufficient quantity, Oyl of Ro≈øes as much as is
≈øufficient, mix them and anoint the brea≈øt.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Bolearmenick pouder'd, green Gauls brui≈øed, each one part, Honey a ≈øufficient quantity, make an Unguent.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Ceru≈ø≈øe, white Marble, each one part, Oyl of Myrtels a ≈øufficient quantity, pouder them and mix them.

div.head: To make the Bre≈øts decrea≈øe or grow le≈øs.
div.p: The juice of Hemlock mixt with Camphure and layd on, makes them le≈øs; al≈øo white Frankincen≈øe with Navel-wort and ≈øharp Vinegar, hinders their growth.

div.head: An Ointment to hinder their growth.
div.p: Take a ≈øufficient quantity of Dyers-earth, boyl it with Honey, and make a thick Poulte≈ø≈øe, and apply it from morning to night, then lay over it a Spunge ≈øoaked in cold water till the Poulte≈ø≈øe be taken off, and if you would have it more effectual, mix with it ten unripe Gauls, it will make them right and ≈øtreight.

div.head: To harden ≈øoft and loo≈øe Brea≈øts.
div.p:
Take clay, the white of an Egge, unripe, Gauls, Ma≈øtick, Frankincen≈øe, each a ≈øufficient quantity, brui≈øe them all and mix them with hot Vinegar, and anoint the brea≈øt,
and ≈øuffer it to lye on all night; if once will not do, do it again.

div.head: To hinder the growth of the Brea≈øts.
div.p: Brui≈øe Hemlock, and let a Ma≈øs of it with Vineger be laid on a Virgins brea≈øt, it will ≈øo confine them that they grow not, though at the time of milk coming in them.

div.head: A Liniment to ≈ømooth flaggy, wrinckled Brea≈øts.
div.p: Take Lees of Oyl, as much as is ≈øufficient, Gum-arabick, Tragacanth, Ma≈øtick, each a little, Camphure a very little, mix them.

div.head: To make the Brea≈øts le≈øs and hard.
div.p: Take of green Mint, dryed Ro≈øes, wilde Pears, Medlars, Servaces, Slooes, Juice of binding Bean-tree, Pomegranate-flowers, Pomegranate-rinde, unripe Pine-nuts, Plantane, Flowers of Archangel, each alike parts, brui≈øe them and boyl them in Vineger, then adde flour of Beans, as much as is ≈øufficient, make a Plai≈øter.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p:
Take of Quinces, unripe Plums, each a ≈øufficient quantity, brui≈øe them very well, and adde Bolearmenick, Plantane-≈øeed, Ani≈øe≈øeed, Fennel, Cummin, each a little, Juice
of Plantane, Vineger, each a ≈øufficient quantity, mix them.

div.head: An Ointment for Brea≈øts that hang down.
div.p: Take of Bean-flower, Frankincen≈øe, Ma≈øtick, Juice of Hou≈øleek, hot Vineger, whites of Eggs, each a ≈øufficient quantity, mix them.

div.head: Another for the ≈øame.
div.p: Take of dried Figs, Rai≈øons, Cummin, Vineger, each as much as is ≈øufficient, brui≈øe them and boyl them to the form of a Plai≈øter.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Gauls, Ma≈øtick, Frankincen≈øe, whites of Eggs, hot Vineger, each as much as will ≈øuffice, mix them: Bran boyled with Vineger and laid on the Brea≈øts, will do the like.

div.head: An Ointment for Clefts of the Nibbles.
div.p: Take Oyl of Ro≈øes, the middle rinde of Elder, each one ounce, Wax as much as is ≈øufficient, mix them.

div.head: Another for pain proceeding of Clefts.
div.p:
Take Oyl of Violets, or Oyl of ≈øweet Almonds, white Frankincen≈øe, Wax, each
two drams, and then mix them.

div.head: Another for Clefts.
div.p: Take Badgers fat half an ounce, Martialum, and Agrippa's Ointment, Ointment of Mar≈øh ‚Ä¢ mallowes, and that called Anodyne, each one dram, Oyl of Nard one ounce and a half, mix them.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take Oyl of Ro≈øes two ounces, new Wax half an ounce, Litharge, Frankincen≈øe, each one dram, mix them.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Tragacanth one ≈øcruple, flour of Starch-corn two ounces, Juice of Plantane three drams, mix them and anoint.

div.head: Ointments to adorn the Belly and Feet.
To take away the Wrinckles of the Belly after Childe bearing.
div.p: TAke of burnt Harts-horn, the ≈øtone Amiantus, Ammoniack, Salt, Myrrhe, Frankincen≈øe, M ‚Ä¢ ≈øtick, each as much as is ≈øufficient, pouder and mix them with Honey.

div.head: Another of the ≈øame.
div.p: Take of Rams Suet, nine times wa≈øht in cold water, one pound, two whites of Egges, a little Butter, brui≈øe them all very well, then adde Ma≈øtick, Olibanum, each two drams, mix them and make an Ointment for the Belly.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Sea-onion burnt, burnt Harts-horn, Plumed-Alume, Ammoniack. Salt, Myrrhe, Olibanum, Ma≈øtick, Gith, Barley-flour, each a like parts, pouder and mix them with honey.

div.head: An Ointment for hardne≈øs of the feet.
div.p: Take the flour of Gith, the flour of old Bread-corn, Wax, each a ≈øufficient quantity, mix them, and make a Cerot to lay on the place.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Drink made with Vineger and Honey, Ammoniacum, each one ounce Bdellium, Sagapen, each two drams, Turpentine three drams, Oyl of Orrice, two ounces, mix them and make an Unguent.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take the a≈øhes of the rinde of Sallow, Vineger, each as much as will ≈øuffice, mix them and anoint the place.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take the green leaves of Rue, Raifons, each a ≈øufficient quantity, brui≈øe them togegether, and make a Plai≈øter.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Galbanum, Wax, each a ≈øufficient quantity, and mix them.

div.head: A brave-≈øcented Ointment.
div.p: Take of Musk, Ambergreece, Sivet, each four granes, with Oyl of ≈øweet Almonds, reduce them to the form of an Ointment.

div.head: Or thus:
div.p: Take Oyl of Nutmegs made by a Pre≈øs, one dram, the be≈øt Sivet one ≈øcruple, choice Musk ≈øix granes, Oyl of Spike, Lavender, each two or three drops, mix them and make an Ointment to anoint the No≈øtrils, Fore-head, and principal parts, to fortifie them.

div.head: A white Sweet-≈ømelling Soap.
div.p:
TAke of old Venetian Soap ≈øcraped, and ≈øix days ≈øet in the ≈øun, as much as is ≈øufficient,

div.p: Take of the be≈øt Soap ≈øcraped one pound, choice Cynamon, Nutmeg, Cane, Styrax, each one ounce, wood of Aloes two drams, Benjamin two ounces, Cloves one ounce, beat them all to a fine powder, and adde powder of Cy ‚Ä¢ erus one dram, Musk, Siver, each a little, dip them in Ro≈øe-water, afterwards ≈øet them in the ≈øun for forty days, and make Balls, which mu≈øt be kept in Cotton in woodden ve≈ø≈øels.

div.p:

A Powder to make them white.
div.p: TAke of red Co ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ al. Date-≈øtone Pummy≈øtone, the bones of the fi≈øh Sepia, burnt Salt, each a ≈øufficient quantity, mix them and make a Powder.

div.p: Take of Hy≈ø≈øope, Organy, Mint, each two ounces, cleft Alume, Harts-horn, common Salt, each one dram, take them and burn them in a pot to coales, then adde Pepper, Pummy-≈øtone, Pellitory of Spain, Ma≈øtick, each half a dram, Myrrhe, Cynamon, each one ≈øcruple, make a fine Powder.

div.p: Take the bones of the fi≈øh Sepia, white Marble burnt, each one ounce, Cloves, Cynamon, Pellitory of Spain, each three ounces, Spunge, Pummy-≈øtone, Salt, each one ounce, mix them and make a fine Powder to rub the Teeth.

div.head: Another.
div.p:

To make the Hands white.
div.p: TAke the flour of Beans, of Lupines, of Starch-corn, Rice, ≈ømall Beanes, Orrice, each ≈øix ounces, mix them and make a Powder, with which wa≈øh the hands in water.

div.p: Take of Pine-nuts clean≈øed and brui≈øed two ounces, Mu≈øtard-≈øeed one pound, Almonds clean≈øed and brui≈øed two ounces; make a Powder and dry it in the ≈øun, with which rub the hands with the Juice of Lemmons, and then with water.

div.p: Take the ≈øeeds of Rocket ≈øix ounces, Orrice, Cummin, each one ounce, dregs of Alume half an ounce, Sugar-candy, Tragacanth, each one ounce, Camphure one ≈øcruple, Pine-nuts, Almonds clean≈øed three ounces, the crum of white bread half an ounce, old Soap ≈øcraped two ounces, pouder them all and mix them, and make a Powder to wa≈øh the hands.

div.p: Take of Ro≈øemary, Mint, Pennyroyal, each half a dram, Orrice-roots, Cammelshay, each one ≈øcruple; Nard, Pepper, each half a ≈øcruple, Pummy-≈øtone, burnt Salt, Harts-horn, each two ≈øcruples, make them up with Tragacanth ≈øteeped in Ro≈øe-water. Sticks of the Ma≈øtick-tree may be found fit to clean≈øe and ≈øtrengthen the teeth.

div.head: Another.
div.p:

and work them into a ma≈øs with Tragacanth ≈øteeped in Ro≈øe-water; of which make Dentifrices like pen≈øils.

div.p: Take of Harts-horn, a Hor≈øes teeth, each two ounces, Sea-≈øhells, common Salt, Cypre≈øs nuts, each one ounce, burn them together in an Oven, and make a Powder, to be wrought up with the mucilage of Gumtragacanth.

div.p: Take of Myrrhe, Ma≈øtick, Frankincen≈øe, each half an ounce, Harts-horn burnt and wa≈øht, red Corral, Ro≈øes, Musky-Saunders, Cloves, each two ≈øcruples, the bone of the fi≈øh Sepia, Roche-alume burnt, each two drams, Pummy-≈øtone one dram and a half, common Salt burnt one dram, make a Powder; you may u≈øe it with a Mallowroot prepared.

div.head: Another eminent one.
div.p:

div.head: A ≈øweet Bag.
div.p: TAke of Cubebs half a dram, Cloves one ≈øcruple, Gith burnt one ounce and a half, Mace two ≈øcruples, pouder them and put them into ≈øilk.

div.p: Take Orrice of Florence half a pound, Ro≈øes four ounces. Cyperus half an ounce, Marjoram, Cloves, each half a dram; ≈øweet-≈øcented white Saunders, Benjamin, each four ounces, Styrax-calamite one ounce, pouder them and put them in ≈øilk for a ≈øcent.

div.head: Another.
div.p:

div.head: Another.

div.head: Another.
div.p:

with the infu≈øion of Gum-tragacanth in Ro≈øe-water.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Styrax-calamite, liquid Styrax, Benjamin, Gallia Mo≈øchata, Alipta Mo≈øchata, Labdanum, each one ounce, choice Cynamon, Cloves, white Saunders, each half an ounce, red Ro≈øes, Nutmeg, Mace, Wood of Aloes, Cardamoms, Marjoram, Gum-Elemni, Gith-≈øeed, Zedoary, each a dram and a half, Turpentine as much as is ≈øufficient, with a little infu≈øion of Tragacanth made in Ro≈øe-water, then make a ma≈øs.

div.head: Another.
div.p:
Take of yellow Saunders ≈øix drams two ≈øcruples, Wood of Aloes half an ounce, red Ro≈øes, Ba≈øilicon, Lavender, Ro≈øemary-flowers, Marjoram, each three drams one ≈øcruple, Citron-pill ≈øeven drams; Cynamon, Nutmeg, Mace, Cloves, Coriander≈øeed prepared, Cardamoms, each three drams one ≈øcruple; pure Labdanum eight ounces, Styrax-calamita ≈øix drams two ≈øcruples, liquid Styrax three ounces, Benjamin ten drams, yellow Wax one ounce and a
half, Turpentine four ounces, Ro≈øe-water two ounces and a half, Musk of Alexandria, Ambergreece, each two ≈øcruples and a half, make a ma≈øs.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take Powder of Violets a dram and a half, Ro≈øes, Marjoram, Styrax-calamite, Labdanum, each one dram, Cloves two drams, Benjamin, Nutmegs, each one ≈øcruple; Ambergreece half a ≈øcruple, make a ma≈øs with Ro≈øe-water, in which Tragacanth and Gumarabick have been ≈øteeped, and ≈øprinkle it with a little Oyl, either of Cynamon, or Cloves, or Nutmegs.

div.p: Take Styrax three drams, Cloves, Cynamon, each two drams, Mace, Nutmeg, each one dram, Wood of Aloes half a dram, Musk, Ambergreece, each three granes, Ma≈øtick one dram and a half, pouder and ≈øear≈øe them, then make them up with the di≈øtilled Water of Marjoram, and liquid Styrax, and make round ≈øweet Balls.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Take of Virgins Wax four ounces, Oyl of Olives, Turpentine, each half an ounce, Labdanum three drams, Olibanum, Ma≈øtick, each a dram and a half, Myrrhe, Styrax-calamite, each two drams, white and red Been, red Ro≈øes, dried Mint, Marjoram, Cloves, Cardamoms, white and red Saunders, Cynamon, Nutmeg, Wood of Aloes, Camphure, each one dram, Ambergreece, Musk, each half a dram, pouder them and make a Pomander.

div.head: A Pomander for the time of Pe≈øtilence.
div.p: Take of Labdanum, Styrax-calamite, each one dram, Cloves half a dram, Camphure, Nard, Nutmeg, each ≈øeven granes, brui≈øe them all to a fine pouder, and mix them with Ro≈øe-water in which Tragacanth and Gumarabick have been ≈øteeped, and make Balls.

div.head: Another.
div.p:
Take of Labdanum three ounces, Styrax-calamite one ounce, Benjamin half an ounce, Cloves three drams, red Ro≈øes two drams, Wood of Aloes, white Saunders, each one dram, Majoram, Lavender, Gith-≈øeeds, each half a dram, Camphure three granes, liquid Styrax half an ounce,
with the infu≈øion of Gum-tragacanth in Ro≈øe-water make a Pomander, the rich may adde a little Musk and Ambergreece.

div.head: A Pomander that will purge.
